contentrichtext.text: {{Infobox person | name = James Whittaker | image = Jim Whittaker 1.jpg | image_size = 200px | caption = Jim Whittaker speaking at the [[Computer History Museum]]. | birth_date = {{Birth-date and age|February 10, 1929 }} | birth_place = [[Seattle]], [[Washington (U.S. state)|Washington]] | death_date = | death_place = | education = [[West Seattle High School]]<br/>[[Seattle University]] | occupation = [[Mountaineering|Mountaineer]] | spouse = | parents = | children = }} :''This article is about the mountaineer. For the [[politician]], see [[Jim Whitaker]].'' '''James W. Whittaker''', also known as '''Jim Whittaker''' (born in [[Seattle]], [[Washington (U.S. state)|Washington]] on February 10, 1929 <ref name="everesthistory">[http://www.everesthistory.com/climbers/whittaker.htm EverestHistory.com: Jim Whittaker]</ref>) is an [[United States|American]] [[Mountaineering|mountaineer]]. As a member of the [[American Mount Everest Expedition 1963]] led by [[Norman Dyhrenfurth]], he was the first American to reach the summit of [[Mount Everest]]. He summited on May 1, 1963 with the [[Sherpa people|Sherpa]] [[Nawang Gombu]] (a nephew of [[Tenzing Norgay]]). They ran out of oxygen but managed to reach the summit. Once there, Whittaker planted a [[flag of the United States|US flag]] at the top.<ref name='ngam'>{{cite news | first=Michael | last=Shnayerson | coauthors= | title=Jim Whittaker, Back on Earth | date=May 2003 | publisher= | url =http://www.nationalgeographic.com/adventure/0305/story.html#story_2 | work =National Geographic Adventure Magazine | pages = | accessdate = 2007-05-07 | language = }}</ref> He is the twin brother of [[Lou Whittaker]], a mountain guide who is often mistakenly credited with that achievement. Whittaker graduated from [[West Seattle High School]] and [[Seattle University]]. He was the first full-time employee of [[Recreational Equipment Inc.]] and was the company's CEO in the 1960s. Now, Whittaker is chairman of the Board of [[Magellan Navigation]], a company that produces handheld [[global positioning system]] (GPS) units. In 1965 he guided [[Robert Kennedy]] up the newly-named [[Mount Kennedy]]. He led the [[Earth Day 20 International Peace Climb]] that brought together climbers from the [[United States]], [[USSR]] and [[China]] to summit Mount Everest. In addition to putting more than a dozen climbers on the summit, the expedition hauled off a large amount of trash left on the mountain by previous expeditions. In 1999 Whittaker released his autobiography, ''A Life on the Edge: Memoirs of Everest and Beyond''. ==Awards and honors== *For being the first American to scale Mount Everest, Whittaker was awarded the [[Hubbard Medal]] by [[President of the United States|United States President]] [[John F. Kennedy]]. {{cquote|If you aren't living on the edge, you are taking up too much space.}} {{cquote|You never conquer a mountain. Mountains can't be conquered; you conquer yourself.}} (This is essentially equivalent to George Mallory's question and answer: "Have we conquered an enemy? None but ourselves," quoted in ''Everest: the West Ridge,'' p. 27. ) ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== *http://www.banffcentre.ca/mountainculture/media/2002/whittaker.htm *Interview with Jim Whittaker (2007) http://video.msn.com/video.aspx?mkt=en-US&brand=&vid=4b543340-5307-4593-83cc-340bb6b2dffe *Sarah Holbrooke intervies Jim Whittaker on Minds of Mountainfilm: http://vimeo.com/5322444 {{Authority control|VIAF=117361602}} {{Persondata <!-- Metadata: see [[Wikipedia:Persondata]]. --> | NAME = Whittaker, Jim | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = American mountaineer | DATE OF BIRTH = February 10, 1929 | PLACE OF BIRTH = [[Seattle]], [[Washington (U.S. state)|Washington]] | DATE OF DEATH = | PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Whittaker, Jim}} [[Category:1929 births]] [[Category:American mountain climbers]] [[Category:People from Seattle, Washington]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Twin people from the United States]] [[Category:Seattle University alumni]] [[Category:American summiters of Mount Everest]] [[Category:Twin sportspeople]]
